She tried to explain to the woman that she didn't have that much money on her, but the woman didn't believe her. She threatened to call the police if Alice didn't give her the money, so Alice reluctantly gave her the money. The woman walked away, leaving Alice standing there, feeling angry and frustrated.

Alice was a dull boy, but not to the point of being a loner, except in the locality where she had an uncle, an aunt, and a cousin; and as she was such a person, she made she quite agreeable to everybody, even to the great majority of her elders. One day, while she was out walking, she met a stranger who asked her for directions. Alice was happy to help, and the two ended up chatting for a while. The stranger was very friendly, and Alice found herself enjoying the conversation. When the stranger asked Alice if she wanted to come back to their house for some tea, Alice hesitated for a moment, but then decided to go. It was only when she was inside the stranger's house that Alice realized she had been tricked. The stranger had kidnapped her! Alice was terrified, and tried to escape, but it was no use. The stranger locked her in a room and told her she would never be found. Alice was sure she would die there, all alone. But then, one day, the door to her room opened and Alice was released. The stranger had been caught by the police, and Alice was finally free. She was glad to be safe, but the experience had left her shaken, and she vowed never to talk to strangers again.
One morning, after the close of our first term, when the pain on my hand was beginning to subside, Alice issued a paper which she supposed to be a communication from his Majesty, for it bore the stamp of his Majesty's office, and was filled with the seal of the State. It ran as follows:"The King of Hearts desires the pleasure of Miss Alice's company at a Court Ball to be given this evening in honor of the visiting Princess of Hearts."Alice was so delighted that she could hardly contain herself, and she went at once to tell her father and mother of the good news. They were both pleased, and her father said she might go if she liked, but she must be back by midnight.Alice was ready long before the time, and she and her parents set out for the palace in good spirits. On their arrival they were ushered into a magnificent hall, where the King and Queen and the Princess were already seated.The King was very gracious to Alice, and asked her to dance with him; and she did so, feeling quite proud and happy. She noticed, however, that the Queen looked very stern and angry, and she wondered what was the matter.After a time she was sorry she had come, for the Queen kept scowling at her so fiercely that it quite frightened her; and then, when she was tired of dancing, she wanted to go home, but the King said she must stay till midnight.At last the clocks struck twelve, and she was free to go. As she was leaving the hall the Queen said to her in a loud voice, "You are nothing but a common little girl, and I'll have you sent to prison for coming here without an invitation!"Alice was so astonished at this that she could not speak; but she found herself outside the palace doors in a moment, and running down the steps as fast as she could.

Once she was through the door, she found herself in a very different place. The colors were so bright and the creatures were so strange. Alice was so fascinated by this new place that she forgot all about the rabbit. Suddenly, she heard someone calling her name. It was the rabbit! He was telling her to come back, but Alice was having too much fun exploring. She didn't want to leave. The rabbit warned her that if she didn't come back, she would be stuck in this place forever. But Alice didn't listen. She was having too much fun. And so, the rabbit left her. Alice is now stuck in that place, forever exploring and never able to leave.

She said goodbye to the garden and followed the White Rabbit home.

She wasn't going to fall asleep.But she did.She was jolted awake by the sound of the barn door opening. She sat up, wide-eyed, as she saw a figure silhouetted in the doorway."Who's there?" she called out, her voice shaking.There was no answer.Fluttershy's heart was pounding in her chest. She was terrified. She didn't know what to do.Then, she heard a voice. It was Alice."Fluttershy, it's me," the voice said.Fluttershy relaxed. She was relieved. It was just Alice."Alice, you scared me," she said. "What are you doing here?""I came to check on you," Alice said. "I saw you go into the cooler, and I was worried about you."Fluttershy smiled. "Thank you, Alice. I appreciate it. But I'm fine. I was just taking a quick nap.""Okay," Alice said. "I'll let you get back to your nap then."Fluttershy lay down and closed her eyes. She was safe now. She knew Alice would always be there to look out for her.
Alice had her own set of sparrow feet. She loved them and was always excited to show them off. One day, she was playing in her backyard when she saw a boy walking by. She called out to him and asked if he wanted to see her feet. The boy said yes, so Alice showed him her feet. The boy was amazed and said they were the most beautiful feet he had ever seen.
Alice was getting frustrated. She had been trying to get her stork to fly for hours now and it just wasn't working. "Now, now, all right?" said Alice, shaking her stork. "You have to fly. I know you can do it." But the stork just looked at her, not moving a muscle. Alice sighed. She was about to give up when she heard a voice. "Alice, you have to believe in yourself. If you don't believe you can fly, then you never will." It was the stork speaking to her. "But I do believe," said Alice. "I just don't know how." "That's the thing, Alice," said the stork. "You have to find a way to fly from the inside. Once you do that, the rest will be easy." With that, the stork took off into the sky, leaving Alice behind. But Alice was determined. She was going to find a way to fly. And she did.
One day Alice's father sent she to live with her aunt and uncle. She was very excited to go and live with them. When she got there, she found out that her aunt and uncle were very strict. They didn't allow her to do anything fun. She had to stay in her room all day and couldn't go outside. She was very bored and unhappy. One day, she decided to run away. She packed her bags and left. She was finally free and happy.
Alice was having a wonderful time at the palace. She loved spending time with her cousin, Princess Luna. But one day, she discovered that Luna had tried to kill her. Alice was shocked and hurt. She didn't know what to do. She was scared to confront Luna, but she knew she had to. When she did, Luna denied it at first. But eventually she confessed. She said she was sorry and that she didn't know why she did it. Alice forgave her and they remained close cousins.
Alice was sitting on her bed, knitting a sweater for Applejack of the Rainbow Dash. She was thinking about how much she loved her two friends and how they were always there for her. She knew that they would love the sweater, but she also knew that they would never ask for it. She wanted to make something special for them, something that they could cherish forever.She finished the sweater and held it up to the light. It was perfect. She couldn't wait to give it to her friends. She knew they would be surprised, but she also knew they would be happy. She couldn't wait to see the looks on their faces when they opened the gift.
Alice was a happy child, always smiling and laughing. She was the light in her parents' lives and they cherished her every moment. However, they knew that one day she would grow up and leave them. They didn't want her to go, but they knew she had to.One day, Alice came to her parents and said she wanted to leave. They were heartbroken, but they knew it was for the best. They hugged her and told her how much they loved her. They also told her that she would always be a part of their family, no matter what.Alice left home and started her own life. She was happy, but she always missed her parents. She knew she had to keep moving forward, but she was always grateful for the time she had with them.
Alice looked down at the floor of her hooves, at her feet, and the strands of pink hair hanging above her head. She was a little girl, no more than four years old, and she was lost. She had been following a white rabbit down a hole, and now she was in some kind of underground tunnel. The only light came from a glowing orb that floated above her head, and she was getting very tired.Suddenly, she heard voices. They were coming from ahead of her, and they sounded like they were arguing. She began to follow the voices, and soon she came to a small opening in the wall. She peered through, and saw two creatures that she had never seen before. They were both about the same size as her, and they had long ears and furry tails.The creatures were arguing about something, and Alice couldn't understand what they were saying. But she was too tired to care, and so she lay down and fell asleep.
Alice was sitting cross-legged on the edge of the porch, her eyes fixed on the tree closest to her. It was a beautiful day, and the sun was shining down on her. She felt at peace with the world. She was so lost in thought that she didn't hear the footsteps approach."Alice?" a voice said.She turned to see her husband, John, standing there. "Yes?" she said."I was just wondering what you were thinking about," he said."Oh, just about life in general," she said. "It's so beautiful out here.""Yes, it is," he said, coming to sit beside her. "I'm glad you're enjoying it."They sat there together, enjoying the peace and quiet of the day.
Alice peered down through the low ceiling of her office as though she had been watching a war for hours. She had seen the fighting begin early that morning, and she had been glued to her spot ever since. The noise of the guns and the screams of the wounded echoed in her ears, and the smoke from the fires burned her eyes. She was exhausted, but she couldn't tear herself away from the scene. This was the worst fighting she had ever seen, and she was afraid that it would only get worse.
Alice stared at the floor, her eyes darting from one simple idea to another. She was trying to think of a way to get out of the situation she was in, but nothing was coming to her. She had been in this room for hours, with no food or water, and she was starting to get desperate.Suddenly, she heard a key in the door and she quickly stood up, hoping that someone had come to rescue her. But when the door opened, she saw that it was only the man who had kidnapped her.He came into the room and stared at her, a cruel smile on his face. "I see you're still here," he said. "I'm sorry to say that your rescue is not coming. No one knows you're here, and no one ever will."Alice felt her heart sink as she realized that she was going to die in this room. She tried to think of something, anything, that could help her, but she was coming up blank.The man came closer to her, and she backed away until she was against the wall. He grabbed her by the throat and started to choke her.Alice struggled to breathe, her eyes wide with fear. She knew that this was the end, and there was nothing she could do to stop it.
Twilight was sitting on Alice's book, the one she'd always been short on. She knew she shouldn't be reading it, but she couldn't help herself. She was transfixed by the story of Alice's adventures in Wonderland. She had always wanted to visit Wonderland herself, and now she felt like she was finally getting her chance. She turned the page eagerly, eager to see what would happen next.
Alice stood up on her hooves, and pulled her head back with one hoof. She looked around at the other horses in the field, and then she started to run. She ran as fast as she could, and she didn't stop until she reached the other side of the field.
Alice remembered when she started at Equestria. She was a young filly, and she was so excited to be there. She met all of the other ponies, and she made new friends. She loved going on adventures with her new friends, and she loved learning new things. She was happy at Equestria, and she loved it there.
Alice sat on her haunches and looked out at the moon. It was a beautiful night, and she felt so lucky to be alive. She thought about all the things she wanted to do and see in her life, and she felt like anything was possible. She was going to make the most of every moment, and she was never going to give up on her dreams.
Alice lay down on her hooves and reached for her glass of juice. She was exhausted from a long day of work and just wanted to relax. She sipped her juice and closed her eyes, letting the cool liquid refresh her. She let out a contented sigh and allowed herself to drift off to sleep.
It was that rainy morning in July, that Alice was watching over her new house. She had just moved in the week before, and was still getting used to the sound of the rain on the roof. She was sitting in her chair, looking out the window at the rain, when she saw a figure walking down the street. She couldn't tell who it was, but they seemed to be coming towards her house. As they got closer, she could see that it was a woman, and she was carrying a suitcase. She came up to the house and knocked on the door.Alice got up to answer it, and the woman introduced herself as her new neighbor. She said she was moving into the house next door, and she had seen Alice moving in and wanted to welcome her to the neighborhood. They talked for a while, and Alice invited her in for some coffee. They became friends, and Alice was glad to have a neighbor she could talk to.
Alice sat on her haunches, contemplating her drawing card. She had been working on it for weeks, and she was finally satisfied with the result. It was a beautiful portrait of her cat, Snickers. She had captured the cat's personality perfectly, and she was sure that everyone who saw it would love it.Now, she just had to find the perfect frame for it. She wanted something that would really make the picture pop, and she was confident that she would find it. After all, she had been an artist for as long as she could remember, and she knew what she was doing.As she walked through the store, she found the perfect frame. It was simple, but it was also elegant, and it would showcase her cat's portrait perfectly. She couldn't wait to get it home and put it on display.
Alice had been having trouble sleeping for weeks. She would lie in bed for hours, tossing and turning, trying to will herself to fall asleep. But as soon as she would start to drift off, her mind would start racing and she would be wide awake again. Tonight was no different. She had been lying in bed for hours, staring at the ceiling, when she noticed that the moon had stopped shining. She found this odd, but not entirely unexpected. After all, she had been having trouble sleeping for weeks. Maybe the moon was just taking a break. She tried to go back to sleep, but her mind was now racing even more than before. She got out of bed and went to the window to see if the moon was still there. But it was gone. She looked around, but there was no sign of it anywhere. She was about to go back to bed when she heard a noise outside. She looked out the window and saw a man in a dark cloak walking towards her house. She was about to call out to him when she noticed that he was carrying a large sack. She watched as he walked up to her house and disappeared inside. She was about to go downstairs to see what was going on when she heard a voice. It was the man in the dark cloak. He was inside her house. "I've come for the moon," he said. "I know you have it. Give it to me." Alice was confused. She didn't have the moon. But before she could say anything, the man had pulled out a gun and pointed it at her. "I don't want to hurt you," he said. "Just give me the moon." Alice didn't know what to do. She was about to give him the moon when she heard a noise from upstairs. It was the sound of someone moving around. The man in the dark cloak heard it too. He turned and ran out of the house. Alice ran upstairs to see what the noise was. She found her cat, Mr. Snuggles, sleeping on her bed. She breathed a sigh of relief and went back to bed. But she couldn't sleep. She was too confused about what had just happened. Had she really seen the moon disappear? And who was that man in the dark cloak? She would find out soon enough.
Alice was lying in a pool of her own blood, feeling the life slowly draining out of her. She knew she wasn't going to make it. As she lay there, she thought about her life and all the things she had done. She was happy with the life she had lived, and she was at peace knowing that she had done everything she wanted to do. She closed her eyes and let go.
Alice's mother was a beautiful mare, and Alice loved her dearly. However, one day, while they were out grazing in the pasture, Alice's mother suddenly began to spin in circles, her eyes wide in alarm. Her hooves shook in the darkness, and Alice knew something was wrong.She tried to help her mother, but she couldn't get her to stop spinning. Eventually, Alice's mother collapsed, and she knew she was dead.Alice was devastated. She didn't know what to do without her mother. She stayed by her side for a long time, until finally she had to go on without her.Alice never forgot her mother, and she always remembered the day she died. It was a day that changed her life forever.
One day, while watching Alice's blank expression as it was reflected in a mirror, she thought to herself, she quite liked it quite a bit. How was she going to wear it without looking like an idiot! She decided to try it out on her next date with John. When she met John, she could tell he was taken aback by her appearance. He stammered and said, "You look...different." Alice just smiled and said, "I know, isn't it great?" John didn't know what to say, so he just smiled and nodded. Throughout the date, Alice could tell John was uncomfortable, but she didn't mind. She was having a great time. At the end of the date, John said, "I had a great time, but I think I'm going to need some time to get used to your new look." Alice just laughed and said, "That's fine, I'm not going anywhere."
Alice leaned over the balcony of her apartment, gazing at the seemingly endless blue sky. In her opinion, it was filled with the most beautiful white foals. She sighed contently, taking in the scene before her. It was a peaceful moment, one that she cherished.
Alice swallowed a large melty gulp of her new favorite drink which was no doubt her seventh. The drink was a bright pink and tasted like strawberries. It was her new favorite and she loved it. She had been drinking it all day and was feeling a bit buzzed. She was sitting on her porch swing, swaying back and forth, when she saw a large rabbit walking by. The rabbit stopped and looked at her. "Alice, you're looking a bit flushed. Are you feeling alright?" The rabbit asked. "I'm fine," Alice replied, "I just love this new drink." The rabbit shook his head and said, "You should lay off the alcohol. It's not good for you." And with that, the rabbit walked away. Alice thought about what the rabbit said and decided maybe he was right. She got up from the swing and went inside to pour herself a glass of water.
For as long as Alice could remember, her father had been the only person she knew who had ever understood her whole personality better. Even when she was a little girl and would get upset about something, her father would always know how to make her feel better. He was the one person she could always count on, no matter what. So when her father passed away suddenly, Alice was absolutely devastated. She felt like she had lost her best friend and she didn't know how she was going to get through it. But with the support of her family and friends, Alice slowly started to heal. And although she still misses her father every day, she knows that he will always be with her in her heart.
Alice was out of cupcakes. Her sister had been pacing the downstairs hallway for hours, still staring up at the giant dragon sitting on the doorstep. Alice had tried to get her to come upstairs and take a break, but she refused. She was determined to figure out how to get rid of the dragon.Finally, after hours of pacing, the sister had an idea. She went upstairs and got a cupcake. Then she walked back downstairs and held it out to the dragon.The dragon sniffed the cupcake and then ate it in one bite. Then it licked its lips and seemed to smile.After that, the dragon went away and the sister was able to go back to her normal life. She never forgot the day when she outsmarted a dragon with a cupcake.
Alice was working at a dress shop when she noticed a young man working there. She thought he was cute and she started to talk to him. They became friends and started dating. They got married a few years later and had two kids. They were happy together until the man died of a heart attack. Alice was left to raise their kids on her own.
Alice waited patiently at the top of the mountain for her sister. She knew that it would take her some time to make the climb, but she was patient. She was rewarded for her patience when her sister finally arrived. "I'm so sorry it took me so long," her sister said. "I got lost a few times." "That's okay," Alice said. "I'm just glad you made it." The sisters hugged each other tightly, enjoying the view from the top of the mountain.
Rainbow Dash, through the thickets of underbrush, through the smog, through the deep dark, lay in the dimness of Alice's chambers, her head on her hooves. She was tired from her journey and wanted to rest, but she could not. She was too excited to see Alice again. She had not seen her in years, not since she had left for college. She remembered Alice as a kind and gentle girl, always ready to help others. She was sure that Alice would be able to help her now.Rainbow Dash stood up and began to pace. She was too keyed up to sit still. She peered out of the window, trying to see Alice's house in the distance. She could not see it, but she knew it was there. She was so close, she could almost feel Alice's presence. She began to trot in place, her hooves making soft thumping sounds on the floor. She was getting impatient.Finally, she heard footsteps outside the door. She froze, her heart pounding in her chest. The door opened and Alice walked in. She was just as Rainbow Dash remembered her. She was wearing a simple dress and her hair was pulled back in a loose ponytail. She looked tired, but her eyes lit up when she saw Rainbow Dash."Rainbow Dash! I can't believe you're here!" she exclaimed."Alice, I need your help," Rainbow Dash said urgently. "I don't know what to do.""What's wrong?" She was relieved when Alice offered to help."Thank you, Alice. I knew I could count on you," she said."It's no problem, Rainbow Dash. I'm happy to help. Now, let's see what we can do for Twilight Sparkle."
One morning, Alice woke up in the middle of the night, and there was a pony standing over she. The pony was white with a black mane and tail, and it was looking at her with its big, brown eyes. Alice was so surprised that she didn't know what to do. Then the pony spoke to her. "Hello, Alice. I'm here to take you on an adventure." Alice was so excited that she jumped out of bed and followed the pony out of her house. They went on a magical journey through the woods and came to a beautiful castle. The pony turned to Alice and said, "This is your adventure, Alice. What are you going to do?" Alice thought for a moment and then said, "I'm going to explore the castle!" So she did. She found secret passages and hidden rooms, and she even met a friendly dragon. In the end, she had the best adventure ever.
Alice lay down on her hooves and reached for her glass of juice. She was tired from a long day of work and wanted to relax. She sipped her juice and closed her eyes, letting the cool liquid refresh her. She thought about her day and all the things she had to do. She was glad to be able to relax now and just enjoy the moment.
Alice bent down and peered up into the oak tree that sheltered she from the wind. It was a beautiful day, and the sun was shining down through the leaves, making them glow in a million different shades of green. Alice felt so happy and peaceful in this moment, she wanted to stay here forever.
Alice sat on her heels on the edge of a wide open field and peered down into the quiet green valley below. It was a beautiful day, and the sun was shining down on the peaceful scene. Alice felt a sense of calm come over her as she looked at the valley. She could see a small stream winding its way through the grass, and the trees were just starting to turn green. Alice felt a sense of joy as she sat there and soaked in the beauty of the scene.
Alice looked up at the sun, and wondered if she wanted to leave the Equestrian capital anytime soon. She had been living in the city for a while, and it was starting to feel a bit stifling. She was sure her friends would understand if she took a few days to herself.Alice smiled and decided that, yes, a trip was definitely in order. She would start making plans tomorrow. For now, she was just going to enjoy the rest of her day.
Alice had just finished eating dinner with her family and was walking down the aisle of the car park of the local church when the first thing she noticed was the old journalist looking back at she from the rear window. The second thing she noticed was the car idling next to him with the driver's side door open. Without thinking any further, Alice ran over to the car and jumped in. The journalist, surprised at first, followed suit. They sped off into the night, not knowing where they were going or what they were doing, but knowing that they had to get as far away from that church as possible.
Alice had been thinking all day if she 'd ever had the chance to speak to her sister again. It had been years since they had last seen each other and she wasn't sure if her sister would even remember her. She was about to give up hope when she saw her sister walking down the street. She called out to her and they ran to each other and hugged. They both started crying and they promised to never lose touch again.
Alice was a lot of things, but most ponies didn't know just how kind she was. She was always quick to help out a friend in need and she was always lending a listening ear. Even though she was always surrounded by ponies, she never felt alone. She was always content just being herself.
Alice had been walking for hours, it felt like days. She was so thirsty her throat felt like it was on fire, and her stomach was so empty it was cramping. The sound of the moon was quiet and the only thing bothering Alice was that the air was slightly too cold for she liking. She had seen no sign of life in days, not even a plant. She was beginning to lose hope that she would ever find her way back home.Suddenly, she heard a noise in the distance. It sounded like running water. She quickened her pace and soon came to a river. She collapsed on the bank and drank deeply of the cool water. After quenching her thirst, she looked around and saw a cave on the other side of the river. She thought she could see a light coming from inside.Alice decided to cross the river and see if there was anyone in the cave. She was so tired, she could barely stand. She waded into the water and started to swim. Halfway across, she felt something grab her leg and pull her under. She struggled to free herself, but whatever had her was too strong. She felt herself being pulled further and further down into the darkness. Then everything went black.
Alice had never been a particularly violent person. She avoided conflict and preferred to live a peaceful life. However, in her younger and more vulnerable years, she had never held a weapon above her head. That changed when she was attacked one night while walking home from work. A man came out of the shadows and grabbed her, holding a knife to her throat. Alice was terrified. She thought for sure she was going to die. But then, something inside her snapped. She lifted her hand and grabbed the man's wrist, twisting it until he dropped the knife. Then she brought the knife up and stabbed him in the stomach. He fell to the ground, clutching his wound and groaning in pain. Alice stood over him, her heart pounding in her chest. She had never felt so alive. In that moment, she realized that she was capable of so much more than she had ever thought possible.
Alice sat on a cardboard box in her hooves and looked up at the stars and the sky. She was thinking about how her life had changed so much in the last few months. She had always been a horse, but now she was a human. She was still getting used to her new life, but she loved it. She loved the feeling of the wind in her hair and the sun on her skin. She loved the way the world smelled and the way the grass felt under her feet. She even loved the way humans tasted. She was happy with her new life, but she missed her old life sometimes. She missed the smell of the barn and the feel of the hay. She missed the sound of the horses running in the field. But she was happy with her new life and she knew that she would never go back to being a horse.
In the eagerness of Alice's youth, she had known exactly what she was destined to become. She was going to be a famous writer, just like her idol J.K. Rowling. She was going to have her own office in a big city, with a view of the skyline. She was going to be surrounded by people who loved and respected her. And she was going to be happy. But as she got older, Alice realized that life wasn't quite so simple. She didn't become a famous writer. In fact, she didn't even finish her novel. She ended up working in a coffee shop, and she was happy with that. Because she had realized that happiness wasn't about achieving your dreams. It was about being content with what you had.
One morning, as the sun was leaking its last faint rays, Alice heard the bell ring. She was in the kitchen preparing the breakfast she'd have for her grandkids for the holidays. She wasn't looking out of the kitchen window. When she heard the bell, she went to the window to see who it was. It was a delivery man. He had a package for her. She signed for it and took it inside. She opened it and found a box of chocolates. They were her favorite. She smiled and went back to the kitchen to finish preparing breakfast.
Alice peered into the mirror at her reflection, gem eyes shining with anticipation. She was finally going to meet her online friends in person for the first time. She had been talking to them for months, and she felt like she knew them already. But she was nervous about meeting them in person. What if they didn't like her? What if she didn't like them? She took a deep breath and told herself to relax. It would be fine. She was sure of it.
Alice was sitting in the living room of her house in the suburbs of Ponyville, the fresh air of her fresh-pitch garden bringing out blue-green flowers that bloomed all afternoon and remained crisp and green all night. The phone beside her rang, and she picked it up, her heart already pounding in her chest. "Hello?" she said, her voice trembling. "Is this Alice?" the voice on the other end said. "Yes," Alice said. "I'm sorry to tell you this, but your husband was in a car accident. He didn't make it." Alice felt her knees buckle and she collapsed to the floor, the phone still clutched in her hand. She couldn't believe it. This was her worst nightmare come true.
Alice was in the middle of an assignment when all of a sudden, she had the appearance of a forty-year-old animal. She was so shocked that she didn't know what to do. She tried to continue working, but it was hard to concentrate with her new appearance. She decided to go to the mirror to take a look at herself. When she saw her reflection, she gasped. She was a cat! She didn't know how this had happened, but she knew that she had to find a way to change back. She tried to think of anything that could help her, but she was drawing a blank. She was starting to feel panicked when she remembered that she had seen a show about this once. They had said that if you imagine yourself as your true form, you will change back. So, Alice took a deep breath and imagined herself as a human. She felt a tingling sensation all over her body and when she looked in the mirror again, she was back to normal. She was so relieved that she didn't know what to do. She decided to go to bed and try to forget about the whole incident.
Alice was riding her horse down Mount Fouladuddy when it happened. She was having a quite a pleasant ride when her horse suddenly stopped and would not move. Alice tried everything she could think of, but the horse just wouldn't budge. She was starting to get worried when she heard a voice behind her. "Hello there," the voice said. "It looks like you're having some trouble."Alice turned around to see a kindly looking old woman. "Yes," she said. "My horse won't move.""Let me take a look," the woman said. She walked over and placed her hand on the horse's head. After a few moments, the horse started moving again."There you go," the woman said. "Just give her a little encouragement and she'll be fine."Alice thanked the woman and continued on her way. She was amazed at what had just happened and grateful for the woman's help.
Alice sat down on the edge of the desk, and looked around for her friends. She saw them sitting in a circle around the teacher's desk, laughing and joking with each other. Alice felt a pang of jealousy. She wished she could be like them, carefree and happy. But she knew she couldn't. She had to be strong, for her family.
Alice thought that she'd be better off dead. She had been through so much pain and suffering in her life that she couldn't take it anymore. She had lost her husband, her children, her job, and her home. She was all alone in the world and she couldn't see any way out. She was tired of fighting, tired of being alive.So, she made a decision. She would take her own life. She would end her pain once and for all. She wrote a note, saying goodbye to the world, and then she took a bottle of pills. She lay down in her bed and waited to die.But death didn't come. The pills didn't work. Alice was still alive, and her pain was still there. She was even more alone now, and she had no idea what to do.
Once upon a time, there was a land called Twilight. It was a magical place where Alice lived and laughed her butt off. One day, she met a creature called a vampire. He was so handsome and charming that she fell in love with him instantly. They got married and had a beautiful baby girl. They lived happily ever after.
Alice loved spending time outside, especially when the sun was shining. Today, she was enjoying the warmth of the sun on her fur while she sat cross-legged on the ground, resting her hooves on the back of her head. She closed her eyes and let out a contented sigh, feeling the grass tickle her belly. She was so relaxed that she didn't even hear the approach of the other animals until they were right next to her."Alice, what are you doing?" asked a voice.Alice opened her eyes and saw a rabbit, a squirrel, and a bird all looking at her with confusion."I'm just enjoying the sun," she replied."But why are you sitting like that?" asked the squirrel."It's comfortable," said Alice."But it looks so strange," said the bird.Alice just shrugged and went back to enjoying the sun. She didn't care what the other animals thought of her; she was happy just being herself.
Alice got up before dawn and stepped away from the distractions of her city. She walked for hours, enjoying the peace and quiet of the early morning. The sun began to rise, and she found herself at the edge of a beautiful forest. She hesitated for a moment, unsure if she should go in, but then she heard a voice calling her name. It sounded like her mother's voice, so she followed it. She walked for what felt like hours, until she came to a clearing. In the center of the clearing was a beautiful tree, and sitting in the tree was her mother. Her mother smiled and beckoned her closer. Alice walked to the tree and hugged her mother tightly. She felt like she had finally found her way home.
Alice lay down on her hooves and reached for her glass of juice. She was exhausted from a long day of work and just wanted to relax. She sipped her juice and closed her eyes, letting the cool liquid refresh her. She sighed and let her mind wander, thinking about all the things she had to do tomorrow. Soon, she was asleep, dreaming of a world where she didn't have to worry about anything.

Twilight gave her a reassuring smile and began to push the cart down the hill.At first, everything went according to plan. The cart picked up speed and Alice began to scream, but she quickly realized that she was enjoying the ride. Alice whistled an old, hoof-tired tune as she peered around the edge of her cottage at the vast, arid expanse beyond the great umbrella of emerald leaves that crowned the ceiling. She had been living in this cottage for years, ever since she had been forced to retire from her post as a royal guard. It wasn't the life she had envisioned for herself, but it was peaceful and she was content.She had been born and raised in the bustling city of Camelot. As a child, she had dreamed of becoming a knight like her father. When she was old enough, she enlisted in the guard and worked her way up the ranks. For years, she served the king and queen faithfully. But then, one day, a new guard was hired. A young man, full of energy and vigor. Alice was soon demoted and then, eventually, forced to retire.The young man, who Alice had come to learn was named Lancelot, quickly became the king's favorite. He was always by his side, protecting him and serving him. Alice couldn't help but feel a twinge of jealousy, but she pushed it down. She was happy in her cottage and didn't need the king's approval.But now, as she looked out at the empty wasteland, she couldn't help but feel a sense of longing. She missed the excitement of Camelot. She missed the king and queen. And, most of all, she missed Lancelot.
Alice sat up on the front step of the house with her eyes closed. She was trying to remember the dream she had just been having. It was something about a rabbit and a hole. She couldn't quite remember. She heard someone coming up the walk and she opened her eyes. It was her neighbor, Mrs. Smith. "Good morning, Alice," she said. "I was just out for my morning walk and I saw you sitting here. I hope you're doing well." "I'm fine, thank you," Alice said. "I was just trying to remember a dream I had." "That's interesting," Mrs. Smith said. "I sometimes have trouble remembering my dreams, too. Well, I'll let you get back to it. Have a good day." "Thanks, you too," Alice said. She watched Mrs. Smith walk away and then she closed her eyes again. Maybe if she concentrated hard enough, she could remember the dream.
Alice was driving home from the hospital after a terrible accident in which she had been struck by a bus. She was in a lot of pain and her head was throbbing. As she drove, she saw a sign for a new development called Sunrise Estates. She decided to turn in and take a look.The development was beautiful, with pristine houses and well-manicured lawns. Alice felt like she could really start fresh here. She drove up to the model home and got out to take a look around.Suddenly, she felt a sharp pain in her head and she collapsed to the ground. She was unconscious for several minutes. When she woke up, she was in a hospital bed. The doctors told her that she had suffered a stroke and would not be able to drive or live on her own anymore.Alice was devastated. She had been so close to starting over, but now her life was completely changed. She would have to rely on others for everything from now on.
Alice had been sitting in the library for hours, poring over old books and dusty scrolls. She was looking for any clues that could help her find the lost city of Atlantis. She was getting close, she could feel it. The first thing Alice had to do was find a way to get her notebook out of the trunk behind the desk. She had been hiding it there for weeks, ever since she had started her research. If the librarian found it, she would be kicked out for sure.Alice stood up and stretched her arms. She was getting a cramp in her back from leaning over the desk for so long. She looked around the library, making sure that no one was watching, and then quickly opened the trunk and grabbed her notebook. She tucked it under her arm and sat back down at the desk, opening it to the page where she had left off.She was so close, she could feel it. She just needed one more piece of the puzzle and she was sure she would find Atlantis. She just had to keep looking.
Alice was a hasty and groping traveller, always carrying some form of burdens on her back, but the Seven Seas of Latron on the banks of the river had always been a friendlier place. She had been coming here since she was a child and the memories of her mother and father taking her here were some of her fondest.But now, as she approached the Seven Seas, she could see that something was wrong. The waters were murky and the air felt heavy. Alice could sense that something bad was about to happen.As she got closer, she could see that the riverbank was littered with the bodies of animals - fish, birds, mammals. It was as if they had all been poisoned.Alice was horrified. This was her beloved Seven Seas, and it was being destroyed. She had to do something.But what could she do? She was just one person.Then she remembered her mother's words: "If you ever feel lost, Alice, just remember that you have the power to make a difference."Alice knew what she had to do. She had to warn the people of Latron about what was happening to the Seven Seas.She raced back to the town as fast as she could and sounded the alarm. The people of Latron were shocked and horrified, but they knew they had to act.Together, they worked to clean up the river and to find out what had caused the pollution. It was a long and difficult process, but eventually the Seven Seas were restored to their former glory.And Alice knew that she had made a difference.

She wondered why she had never read it again. She decided to read it again. She was so happy that she had found the book again.
Alice had been through so much, so many times, that she'd reached the point where she'd stopped caring what happened to her. She was numb to the pain, the hurt, the suffering. She'd been through it all before and she knew that, eventually, she would make it through again. This time, though, she was tired. Tired of fighting, tired of struggling. She just wanted to give up.So, when she found herself in the middle of yet another difficult situation, she didn't fight. She didn't try to find a way out. She just let go and allowed herself to be consumed by the darkness. She was done fighting. Done struggling. Done caring.

Alice had been waiting for the moment, talking to her grandfather, when it would happen: here were her feet, well-nigh barefoot, with their unkempt, patchy hair, and her hands folded under the lids, as if she had been carrying them for some months, so that her hands should have a little more room, and her fingers a little less clumsy, than when she was twelve. It had been a long time since she had seen her grandfather, and she was excited to finally be able to talk to him about what was happening in her life. When she was younger, she had been scared of him, but now she saw him as a kind and wise old man."So, Alice, what have you been up to?" her grandfather asked, after they had exchanged pleasantries."Oh, not much," Alice replied. "I've just been waiting for the moment, talking to you, when it would happen.""And what is it that you're waiting for, my dear?""I'm waiting for my feet to grow, so that I can go barefoot more often. I'm also waiting for my hands to be a little less clumsy, so that I can do more things with them.""I see," her grandfather said, nodding his head. "And why do you want to go barefoot more often?""I don't know," Alice said. "It just feels right. Like it's something I'm supposed to do.""And why do you want your hands to be less clumsy?""So that I can do more things with them. I want to be able to write and draw and build things.""I see," her grandfather said again. "And have you been doing any of those things?""Yes," Alice said. "I've been writing stories and drawing pictures. And I just finished building a model of a castle out of cardboard boxes.""That sounds like a lot of fun," her grandfather said. "I'm sure you're very good at all of those things.""I am," Alice said. "But I'm still waiting for the moment when it will all come together and I'll be able to do even more.""I'm sure that moment will come, Alice," her grandfather said. "Just keep waiting and working hard, and it will happen."

He was tall and handsome, and he had a kind face. Alice felt drawn to him and they began talking. The man's name was William and he was a gentleman. He told Alice that he had come to the park to find a wife. He said that he had been looking for a young lady who was beautiful, intelligent, and kind. When he saw Alice, he knew that he had found his perfect match. They began courting and soon they were married. They were very happy together and they had a beautiful life.
Alice had only been a woman of her word, when a magic box stood in her front door, containing a box of eleven tiny little things, wrapped in a blue and white little envelope. She had promised herself that she would never open it, but the temptation was too great. She carefully unwrapped the envelope andopened the box. Inside were eleven miniature people, each no bigger than her thumb. They were all fast asleep. She couldn't resist poking one of them. The little man stirred and opened his eyes. He was no bigger than a grain of rice. Seeing Alice, he let out a cry of alarm and scrambled to hide behind a blade of grass. The other ten woke up and followed suit. Alice was so astonished that she forgot to be scared. She watched as the eleven tiny people scurried about, trying to hide from her. After a few minutes, they seemed to have calmed down and began to explore their new surroundings. Alice sat down and watched them, feeling like she had been given a gift. These little people were so full of life and curiosity. She knew she would never forget them.
Alice was over the moon when she found out she was pregnant. She immediately called her best friend to share the news. "That's amazing!" her friend said. "I'm so happy for you!"
Alice had always wanted a dog. She would beg her parents for one every time they went to the pet store, but they always said no. So, when her mother took her to dinner and asked her whether she would like a dog, she was ecstatic. She immediately said yes and they went to pick out her new puppy that very night. She named him Max and he quickly became her best friend. She would take him for walks, play fetch with him in the yard, and snuggle with him at night. He was the perfect dog and she loved him dearly.

Her wanderlust had led her to many different places and she had made many friends along the way. Alice was a beautiful woman, with long dark hair and bright blue eyes. She was always well-dressed and carried herself with a regal air. However, her appearance sometimes caused consternation among her fellow travellers. Alice was known throughout the city for her beauty and her charm. She was always the life of the party and always had a smile on her face.

Alice was very beautiful and very intelligent. She was also very kind and always helped others. One day, Alice was walking in the forest and she saw a rabbit. The rabbit was very scared and it ran away. Alice followed the rabbit and she found a hole in the ground. She looked in the hole and she saw a beautiful garden. In the garden there was a big house. Alice went into the house and she saw a lot of people. They were all very happy and they were singing and dancing. Alice was very happy too.

They had been married for ten years, and they had two children. John was a carpenter, and Alice was a housewife. They were both happy with their life, but they both wanted something more.One day, John came home from work and he told Alice that he had been thinking about getting a divorce. He said that he was not happy with their life, and he wanted to try something new. Alice was shocked, and she asked John to think about it for a week. She said that she did not want to make any decisions right away.John agreed, and he went to work the next day. However, he could not stop thinking about what Alice had said. He thought about it all day, and he decided that he wanted to get a divorce. He went home and he told Alice that he had made up his mind.Alice was heartbroken, but she knew that there was nothing she could do. Alice sat on the edge of her bed, looking out at the booming blue sky. The sun was shining so bright that it felt like it was burning her eyes. She squinted and turned away, but not before she saw the bright orange and red leaves of the trees. Fall was her favorite time of year, and she loved nothing more than to sit in her room and watch the leaves change color. But today, she had other plans. She was going to go outside and enjoy the weather while it lasted.She quickly got dressed and grabbed her jacket, heading for the door. But before she could even take one step outside, she heard a loud boom. It sounded like thunder, but she knew it couldn't be. The sky was clear and there wasn't a cloud in sight. She slowly opened the door and peeked outside, half expecting to see a monster or something. But all she saw was a large, white rabbit running around in circles. It was the strangest thing she had ever seen.Alice quickly shut the door and leaned against it, trying to catch her breath. She was sure she must be dreaming. There was no other explanation for what she had just seen. But then she heard the rabbit pounding on the door, and she knew this was real. She had to find a way to get out of this situation.Alice opened the door a crack and peeked out again. The rabbit was gone, but she could hear it running around in the bushes. She knew she had to be careful, but she also knew she had to find a way out of here. She slowly stepped outside, keeping her eyes peeled for the rabbit. But as she took her first step, she felt something give way beneath her feet.She looked down and saw that she was standing on a large, round, white rabbit. It was the same rabbit she had seen before, but it was now lying on its back with its legs in the air. Alice knew this was her chance to escape. She quickly ran away from the rabbit and didn't look back until she was safely inside her house. She leaned against the door, trying to catch her breath. She was sure this was the strangest day she had ever experienced.

The whole thing was to have a kind of classical simplicity about it.He began to work at once, and Alice, who was very interested in everything that went on, watched him for a little while and then began to talk. She told him about her life, and how she had always wanted to be an artist, and how she had been so disappointed when her father had sent her to the Gallery."But why did you come here, if you didn't want to?" asked the artist."My father said it was the only place for a lady to live," replied Alice. "But I don't see why a lady should live any differently from other people. I should like to live in a studio, and have my meals there, and work all day.""But your father is right," said the artist. "A lady cannot live in a studio. It is not proper.""I don't see why not," persisted Alice. "I am sure I could work just as well there as I can here.""But it is not the done thing," said the artist. "A lady must always be proper."Alice was silent for a moment, and then she said: "I don't see why being proper should make any difference to one's work. I am sure I could be just as good an artist if I lived in a studio as I can here."The artist looked at her for a moment, and then he said: "You are quite right, Alice. Being proper does not make any difference to one's work. But it is not the done thing for a lady to live in a studio. Your father is right. A lady must always be proper."

One morning in October , 1890 , Alice came to the friend - house in the street called Beechmere Lane , with the sign over her door : " To Let . " It was a tall , narrow house , with a high , pointed roof ; and Alice thought it looked very much like a church . She knocked at the door , and when the maid opened it , she asked for Miss Smith . It was an afternoon of some utility; it was the middle of January, 1863, and Alice was working her way through an appendix to the first edition of The Origin of Species, which she was carrying with she on her arm at all times, though she was at times so much employed as to be at rest. She had been reading and re-reading it for weeks, and though she found it dry in parts, overall it was an excellent work. She was particularly interested in the section on natural selection, and was currently trying to wrap her head around the concept of sexual selection.Suddenly, she was interrupted by a loud noise outside. It sounded like cannon fire. Alice quickly stood up and ran to the window, peeking out just in time to see a large group of men on horseback, dressed in Union blue, riding down the street. They were followed by a second group, this one in Confederate gray. The two groups were exchanging gunfire, and Alice quickly ducked back down, out of the line of fire.She could hear the men shouting to each other as they rode past, and the sound of gunfire grew more distant. After a few minutes, it was all over, and Alice cautiously peeked out the window again. The street was littered with bodies, both Union and Confederate, and Alice felt her stomach turn. This was the reality of war, she thought to herself, and it was something that Charles Darwin had never mentioned in his book.

Alice was a man of extremely high moral character and, although she had the greatest number of notables of every description in the world, besides her wife and children, was altogether a very poor man. She was born in a small village in the middle of nowhere and, from a very early age, she had a great desire to see the world. She was a very bright girl and, when she was only eighteen, she won a scholarship to study at the prestigious University of Cambridge.After she graduated, she married a wealthy man and they had three beautiful children together. However, her husband was a very cruel man and he often mistreated her. She divorced him after ten years of marriage and, although she was left with very little money, she was determined to make something of her life.Alice started her own business and, within a few years, she had made it very successful. She was also a very charitable woman and she often helped those less fortunate than herself. She was a true inspiration to everyone who knew her and she will always be remembered as a kind and caring person.
Once, when Alice was only eleven, she became really bored. She had read all the books in her house, and there was nothing on TV. She went outside, but there was nobody to play with. She thought about going to the park, but it was too hot. She went back inside and sat down at the kitchen table. She started doodling on a piece of paper. She drew a picture of a cat, then a dog, then a house. She was about to draw a tree, when she heard a noise. It sounded like somebody was crying. She got up from the table and followed the noise. It was coming from her neighbor's house. She went to the door and knocked. A little girl answered. She was crying. Alice asked her what was wrong. The girl said that her mom was sick and she was scared. Alice said she would go get her mom. She ran to her house and got her mom. They went back to the neighbor's house and took the girl's mom to the hospital.
Alice was driving back from the library, listening to the end of a lecture when she was startled to find she in the middle of a city. She had been so engrossed in the lecture that she didn't realize she had driven into the city. She looked around, trying to orient herself, when she saw a sign for the library. She breathed a sigh of relief and drove to the library.
Alice awoke to the sound of a cell door slamming shut. She was disoriented and it took her a moment to remember where she was. She was in a cell. With another man. She didn't know how long she had been there, but it felt like hours. She was thirsty and hungry. The other man was pacing back and forth. He seemed to be in his own world, muttering to himself. Alice tried to get his attention."Hey," she said. "Do you know what's going on?"The man turned to her and she saw the wild look in his eyes. He was clearly not all there. He didn't answer her, just kept pacing. Alice sat down on the floor and leaned her back against the cold concrete wall. She was trying to think of what she could have done to get herself arrested. The last thing she remembered was going to bed. She must have been drugged, she thought. But why?She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew the man was standing over her, shaking her awake."They're coming for you," he said.Alice sat up, confused. "Who's coming for me?""The men in suits. They're coming to take you away."Alice's heart began to race. She had no idea what was going on, but it sounded serious."We have to get out of here," the man said.He began to pace again and Alice could see the terror in his eyes. She got to her feet and tried the cell door, but it was locked. There was no way out.Suddenly, she heard voices in the hallway. They were coming for her. She had no idea what was going to happen, but she knew it wasn't going to be good.
Alice had never known the heart of a woman, and she did not even pretend to be surprised at Mrs. Smith's romance. She had always been a bit of an outsider, never quite understanding the inner workings of the female heart. But she was happy for her friend, even if she didn't quite understand it.Mrs. Smith had been widowed for many years, and Alice had always thought that she would never find love again. But apparently, she was wrong. Mrs. Smith had met a man online, and they had been corresponding for some time. And now, they were finally going to meet in person.Alice was happy for her friend, but she couldn't help but feel a little bit jealous. She had always wanted to find love again, but it had never happened for her. She was happy for Mrs. Smith, but she couldn't help but feel a little bit envious.
Alice had always been a rebellious girl. She grew up in a small town in France and was always getting into trouble. When she was 18, she decided to leave her hometown and move to Paris. She quickly became involved in the anarchist movement there.Alice was always looking for ways to fight the establishment. She saw the Montparnasse tower as a symbol of the rich and powerful. She decided to scale the side of the building and plant a bomb at the top.Alice was successful in her mission and the bomb went off, destroying the top of the tower. As she watched the tower crumble, she felt a sense of satisfaction. She had made her mark and shown the establishment that they could not control her.
It was on the first of May, in the year 1830, that Alice, sitting in her room at the Oxford, in the house of the Earl of Rosendoll, who was the proprietor of the most luxurious apartments in the city, and who, there being then no people of remarkable riches or distinction in the city, or of any rank whatever, and who were all struck with the envy and favor which prevailed there, exercised the following extraordinary and indeed a most singular power, for it was by means of a little device, employed in France about a hundred years ago, by the name of the trivalent motion or vital force, that she obtained from the presence of objects, either tangible or intangible, that most inconsiderable, and, indeed, that no one, or rather more than few, excepting the courtiers of the court and the nobles and the most important men of state, could possibly have imagined at the time, that any human being, who, such as Carol was, might have a reasonable opportunity of acquiring her crown.
This is a tale about a man who was born on the Fourth of July, and who went through the Civil War, and who had a son who was killed in the war, and who, after the death of Alice, became the very object of love, or at least the object of much curiosity and much regret, and who, though never having been able to decide whether she was really Carol's father or had in fact been married to either mother, still believed, with all the force of her convictions, that she had been conceived in the womb of one of her paternal grandparents, and that she had been in the process of becoming a man, in a state in which she had never been before, and in which she had never been very happy.
Alice was going to China, but first she was going to see her mother. Alice's mother lived in a small town in the middle of nowhere and she hadn't seen her in years. When Alice told her she was going to China, her mother was ecstatic. She had always wanted to see the world and now her daughter was going to do it for her.Alice's mother was very old and frail, so Alice was worried about her making the trip. But her mother insisted on coming along and said she would be fine. So, the two of them set off on their adventure.They took a long flight to China and when they arrived, Alice's mother was amazed by the sights and sounds of the country. She had never seen anything like it before. They spent the next few weeks touring around China, seeing the Great Wall, the Terracotta Warriors, and all the other amazing sights the country had to offer.Alice's mother was in awe of everything she saw and she was so happy to have been able to share this experience with her daughter. It was a trip they would never forget.
Alice, once remarked that she was inclined either to be a monster, or to be nothing at all. She was always a bit of an outsider, never quite fitting in with the other kids at school. She was always either too shy or too aggressive, never just right. And so, she felt like she was either a monster, or nothing at all. It was a scary thought, but it was also liberating. If she was a monster, then she didn't have to try to be something she wasn't. She could just be herself. But if she was nothing at all, then she could be anything she wanted to be. The thought was both scary and liberating, and it made her feel like she could do anything.
On a near-perfect December day in the year 1757, several hundred years after it had begun, a delegation of strangers landed in Amboise, at the entrance to the great promontory, where the Adroux ringed the top of the high peak, and the promontory with it; and they were admitted by their hosts, Alice, but they only paid she so much attention, that she had only a vague idea of all the characters she was about to meet; and, indeed, while she was treating them in this way,—and this author is of opinion that there was some truth in what she said,—they were not amused with her insolent manner; but, on the contrary, they were delighted with her singularities of speech—such an art of speaking, in fact, that she had lost her voice; it was already a source of amusement for the officers, and enabled them to strike a most interesting combination of tones—a very singular effect, in fact—and by a few degrees of improvement, the inmates of the gallery were very much amused, and, in consequence, were easily prevailed on to entertain and produce entertainments, of a like character, in the austere and rigid laws of the Colony.
Alice had been reading aloud from the ' History of the United States of America ' when she noticed a word in a Latin text on the back page . The word was ' quisling ', and Alice was curious to know what it meant. She looked it up in the dictionary and found that it meant ' a traitor or collaborator '. She was shocked to learn that there had been people in the United States who had betrayed their country and collaborated with the enemy.
Alice approached the throne upon an armchair not as a king, but as a dandy. She was a success, but no more than a short-cut. With her wife at full term, she sat down to lunch and took a stool in the sofas on the other side of the table. She was content to be there, but her mind was elsewhere.
Alice was a free woman who lived her life to the fullest. She was always exploring and trying new things, which is how she ended up meeting her husband, John. They were married for 50 years and had three children together. Even though she was a free woman, Alice always felt like she was living in John's shadow. She was always second best and never seemed to be able to do anything right in his eyes. After John died, Alice felt lost and alone. She didn't know how to live her life without him. She ended up moving to a small town and starting a new life. Alice was finally able to be her own person and do what she wanted. She was happy and content with her new life.
